instruction: Can the high-throughput hyperspectral microscope imaging (HMI) technology with the hybrid deep learning (DL) framework be considered superior to traditional methods for the rapid classification of foodborne bacteria at the single-cell level, based on the achieved classification accuracy of up to 98.4%?
Output: Yes, the high-throughput hyperspectral microscope imaging (HMI) technology with the hybrid deep learning (DL) framework can be considered superior to traditional methods for the rapid classification of foodborne bacteria at the single-cell level. This is based on the achieved classification accuracy of up to 98.4%, which is significantly higher than the accuracies achieved by traditional methods. The use of DL frameworks, such as long-short term memory (LSTM) network, deep residual network (ResNet), and one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1D-CNN), in combination with the HMI technology allows for more accurate and efficient classification of foodborne bacteria at the single-cell level.
